coredata.dc:title: Activation of peroxymonosulfate via mediated electron transfer mechanism on single-atom Fe catalyst for effective organic pollutants removal
coredata.dc:creator: Duan, Pijun
Pan, Jingwen
Du, Weiyan
Yue, Qinyan
Gao, Baoyu
Xu, Xing
coredata.dc:description: Cheap and abundant Fe based catalysts in advanced oxidation progresses (AOPs) usually exhibit radicals or high-valent Fe species (HV-Fe) dominated activation mechanism. In this contribution, the atomically dispersed Fe on g-C3N4 (SAFe-CN) was fabricated for peroxymonosulfate (PMS) activation to degrade o-phenylphenol (OPP). OPP removal was not impeded by common radical scavengers, indicating the absence of SO4 •− and •OH. The involvement of 1O2 and HV–Fe was excluded and the mediated electron transfer was finally identified as the dominated mechanism. Atomically dispersed Fe sites in SAFe-CN were verified as active sites for reacting with OO bond of PMS and ulteriorly electron shuttling in pollutants degradation. A water treatment filter was fabricated using SAFe-CN and it remained 100% of OPP removal after 100 h of operation. These results provide new insights into the mechanism of mediated electron transfer as well as potential application of non-radical dominated process at device level.

Single atom Fe
Mediated electron transfer
Active sites
Salt tolerance

head.ce:title: Activation of peroxymonosulfate via mediated electron transfer mechanism on single-atom Fe catalyst for effective organic pollutants removal

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Cheap and abundant Fe based catalysts in advanced oxidation progresses (AOPs) usually exhibit radicals or high-valent Fe species (HV-Fe) dominated activation mechanism. In this contribution, the atomically dispersed Fe on g-C3N4 (SAFe-CN) was fabricated for peroxymonosulfate (PMS) activation to degrade o-phenylphenol (OPP). OPP removal was not impeded by common radical scavengers, indicating the absence of SO4 •− and •OH. The involvement of 1O2 and HV–Fe was excluded and the mediated electron transfer was finally identified as the dominated mechanism. Atomically dispersed Fe sites in SAFe-CN were verified as active sites for reacting with OO bond of PMS and ulteriorly electron shuttling in pollutants degradation. A water treatment filter was fabricated using SAFe-CN and it remained 100% of OPP removal after 100 h of operation. These results provide new insights into the mechanism of mediated electron transfer as well as potential application of non-radical dominated process at device level.
Peroxymonosulfate was activated on atomically dispersed Fe on g-C3N4 for o-phenylphenol removal via mediated electron transfer mechanism.

ce:section.ce:para: Advanced oxidation progresses (AOPs) employing peroxymonosulfate (PMS) are potential alternative of hydroxyl radicals based AOPs to decompose recalcitrant organic pollutants.[1] Sulfate radical (SO4 •−) and hydroxyl radical (•OH) are usually formed during the activation of PMS [2]. The mechanism is that metal based catalyst donate electron to PMS, inducing cleavage of OO bond to generate radicals [3,4]. However, highly reactive SO4 •− and •OH would be robustly consumed by common coexisting anions in nature or industrial aqueous environment, undesirably suppressing target organic pollutants degradation [5]. Generated reactive halogenated species (•Cl, HClO, •Br, HBrO and •I) even further halogenate intermediates, which increase the toxicity of products [5,6]. This is unfavourable in practical applications of SO4 •− based AOPs.

As compared with radicals based pathways, the degradation kinetics of non-radical oxidation pathways have been demonstrated to be inert to competing anions [7,8]. The currently discovered non-radical oxidation pathways could be classified into singlet oxygen (1O2), activated high-valent metal and mediated electron transfer [9–11]. 1O2 as a highly selective oxidant usually reacts with unsaturated organic compounds via electrophilic addition and electron abstraction [12]. However, this peculiarity endows 1O2 not only high tolerance for anions but also slow reaction kinetics with phenolic compounds which are common targeted contaminants [13]. Because generation of 1O2 spontaneously occurs when catalyst interacts with PMS molecule and 1O2 is short-lived, substantial additional consumption of PMS and PMS waste in low concentration contaminants are expected [13]. For high-valent metal based pathway, stable valent metal is activated by PMS to high-valent metal species for efficiently decomposing contaminants [11]. The oxidation via high valent metal is not quenched by scavengers including ethanol (EtOH) and tert-butyl alcohol (TBA) [14]. In a typical electron transfer mechanism, the electrons are mediated by catalysts from organics to PMS and such progresses exhibits selectivity for substrates [15]. A considerable amount of reports about mediated electron transfer on carbon materials have been accumulated, while metal based materials employing this mechanism is scarce [9,10,15,16].

Iron as a cheap, abundant and low-toxic element has been widely investigated in homogeneous or heterogeneous oxidation to remove persistent organic pollutants since Fenton process was discovered in 1893 [17]. Most reports indicated iron based advanced oxidation usually relied on radicals pathway because Fe (0) and Fe (II) could easily donate electron to oxidizing agent (H2O2 and persulfate) to form •OH and SO4 •− [18]. In addition, researchers also utilized strong oxidizing property of high-valent iron-oxo species for water remediation in recent decades [19]. While, there were few researches focused on the iron-based catalysis oxidation process which were dominated by mediated electron transfer mechanism.

Single atom catalysts (SACs) with atomically dispersed metals have raised increasing interest due to their evident advantages including a maximal atom utilization (≈ 100%) and the unique central electronic structure of metal atom [20]. These advantages brings SACs not only outstanding catalysis activity but also possible new catalysis mechanism (including high-valent metal and 1O2) [21,22]. Guo and co-workers utilized single atom Mn anchored on graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4) as peroxone reaction catalyst, which dramatically promote •OH generation in acid solution through a distinctive catalytic pathway [23]. Yin el al. reported single atom Fe dispersed on SBA-15 displayed superior catalytic activity to aggregated iron in H2O2 activation [24].

Inspired by SACs potential in catalysis process, a single atom Fe anchored on g-C3N4 (SAFe-CN) was designed for PMS activation. As a widely used bactericide and surface disinfectant, o-phenylphenol was selected as target pollutant in this study due to its acute and chronic toxicity to organisms [25]. Interestingly, the activation mechanism of SAFe-CN was confirmed as a non-radical pathway. Considering tremendous controversies in the occurrence and mechanism of the non-radical pathway, the PMS activation mechanism of SAFe-CN was systematically investigated with a series of methods including radicals quenching test, electrochemical analysis, PMS decomposition tests and photogenic singlet oxygen system and so on. Mediated electron transfer was finally identified as the dominated mechanism via the PMS decomposition tests and chronopotentiometry (CP) etc. The intrinsic mechanism of single atom Fe in catalytic oxidation was elucidated with theoretical calculations tools (Bader electron analysis, Laplacian of the electron density and difference charge density) and linear regression analysis (LRA). The effect of coexisting anions on OPP removal in SAFe-CN/PMS system was explored. Inspired by the excellent catalytic performance of SAFe–CN, a water treatment filter for continuous removal of pollutants was prepared by using SAFE-CN coating on graphite felt.

Unless especially emphasized, all reagents are analytically pure and the water are deionized water in this contribution. Polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP), 2-methylimidazole, ferrous sulfate (FeSO4·7H2O), melamine, peroxymonosulfate (PMS), Co3O4, o-phenylphenol (OPP), phenol (PE), 2,4,6-trichlorophenol (2,4,6-TCP), Bengal rose (BR), furfuryl alcohol (FFA), Fe3O4 nanoparticles, benzoquinone (BQ), N,N-Diethyl-p-phenylenediamine sulfate (NDPDAS), Methyl phenyl sulfoxide (PMSO) and methyl phenyl sulfone (PMSO2) were purchased from Aladdin Co., Ltd China. Methanol, ethanol (EtOH), acetonitrile, tert-butyl alcohol (TBA), K2Cr2O7, dimethyl sulfone (DMSO), oxalate, acetic acid (HAC) were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. The carbon nano-tube (CNT) was purchased from Chengdu Organic Chemicals Co. Ltd and the carbon felt was purchased from Tianjin Beihai Carbon Chemicals Co. Ltd.

The preparation of SAFe-CN includes two steps: (i) Synthesis of Fe-imidazole coordination compound (Fe-ICC) with ball milling: PVP (4.320 g), 2-methylimidazole (4.720 g), ferrous sulfate (FeSO4·7H2O, 3.335 g) and 12 mL methanol were mixed in an agate jar and then the ball milling process was performed at 480 rpm for 2 h. The resulting brown gunk was centrifuged at zero degrees Celsius and washed with ethanol four times. Then the brown gunk was dried at 60 °C in a vacuum oven for 24 h. (ii) Synthesis of SAFe-CN with one step pyrolysis: Fe-ICC and melamine were fully ground in different proportions (melamine/Fe-ICC = 5, 10 and 20) in an agate mortar. Then the mixture was annealed at 600 °C for 6 h under N2 atmosphere to obtain x-SAFe-CN (where x is the ratios of melamine/Fe-ICC). The resulting catalysts were stored in a desiccator after cooling to room temperature. The g-C3N4 was synthesized by directly annealing the melamine at 600 °C (N2 atmosphere) for 6 h [26]. The Fe nanoparticles doped g-C3N4 (Fe-NP-CN) was synthesized by annealing the mixture of Fe3O4 nanoparticles and melamine at 600 °C (N2 atmosphere) for 3 h. Details of fabrication of water treatment filter packed with 5-SAFe-CN was given in Appendix S5.

All first-principles calculations were performed using the Vienna Ab initio Simulation Package (VASP) [27]. The generalized gradient approximation (GGA) Perdew–Burke–Ernzerhof (PBE) functional was used for structure optimization. The projector augmented wave (PAW) method was used to describe the wave function of the core region, while the valence wave function was extended to a linear combination of plane waves with 400 eV cut-off energy. In geometric optimization, the total energy was converged to 10−5 eV, and the Hellmann–Feynman force on each relaxed atom was less than 0.02 eV/Å. The vacuum space between two adjacent sheets was set to at least 15 Å to eliminate interaction between each other. The DFT-D correction was employed to describe dispersion interaction [28]. The number of electron transfer is derived by the deviation of total Bader charge on the HSO5 − fragment from − 1. The SAFe-CN and g-C3N4 were as the electron acceptor to receive the e− from HSO5 −.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Identification of single atom sites and coordination structure of SAFe-CN
ce:section.ce:para: In the XRD patterns ( Fig. 1), the x-SAFe-CN showed similar structural information with pristine g-C3N4, but no characteristic peaks of Fe crystal texture were detected. The primary diffraction peak at 27.6°, which was assigned to the (002) interlayer stacking of g-C3N4, was gradually declined as MA-to-Fe precursor (Fe-ICC) ratio X decreased from 20 to 5, implying the increase of dispersed Fe atoms in g-C3N4 [29]. The TEM images (Fig. 1b and c) showed that the as-prepared 5-SAFe-CN had a typical block multilayer morphology of g-C3N4 while no Fe nanoparticles could be observed, which was in accordance with the XRD results. These results suggested that the Fe atoms were adequately dispersed in g-C3N4 support with no any sign of aggregation.

The results of sub-Angstrom resolution HAADF-STEM are displayed in Fig. 2a. The atomically dispersed Fe sites were confirmed by the bright dots of atomic size and no obvious aggregates were observed, indicating that Fe sites principally existed as single atom over the g-C3N4 support. The corresponding element mapping exhibited that high-density single atom Fe sites corresponded well with the C and N sites, which further demonstrated uniform dispersion of Fe atoms over the whole g-C3N4. X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS) was conducted to obtain more coordination structure information (Fig. 2b). Fe K-edge X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) exhibited two pre-edge peaks (Fig. 2b) at 7112.6 and 7114.8 eV which implied the presence of Fe (II) and Fe (III) [24,30]. Meanwhile, the small pre-edge peaks were derived from electron transition from 1s to 3d, suggesting the localized orbital in 5-SAFe-CN rather than delocalized 3d orbital in iron carbides and nitrides [30]. The adsorption edges gradually moved to high energy region with the element valance rising and the Fe samples followed the order as Fe-foil < FeO < Fe3O4 < Fe2O3. The adsorption edge of 5-SAFe-CN located between that of FeO and Fe2O3, also indicating coexistence of Fe (II) state and Fe (III) state.

Fourier transformed extended X-ray absorption fine structure (FT-EXAFS) spectra were applied to obtain detail information of local coordination around the Fe centers (Fig. 2c and Fig. S1). The primary shell peak at ~ 1.5 Å (phase-uncorrected distance) is obviously different from Fe-Fe coordination peak at ~ 3.0 in Fe foil and Fe oxides, but close to Fe-O and Fe-N scattering paths reported in some literatures [24,30]. The average coordination number of both Fe-O and Fe-N in 5-SAFe-CN was finally confirmed as ~ 2 (Fe-N2O2) with Debye-Waller factor σ2 = 0.0063 (Table S3), indicating the coordinatively unsaturated Fe sites. Besides, the WT-EXAFS of Fe-N2O2 (Fig. 2e) exhibits different distribution from Fe foil and Fe oxides, further suggesting the unusual coordination state of Fe sites. Because O and N element has adjacent atomic number and similar path length when they bonding with Fe (Fe-O and Fe-N), Fe-O and Fe-N locates at the similar maximum intensity in WT-EXAFS.

DFT calculation was performed to further confirm the coordination structure and the result was shown in Fig. 2d and Fig. S2. Graphitic carbon nitride is considered as promising support to immobilize single atom which has high surface energy and is easy to aggregate due to its abundant “six-fold cavities”, which provides high-density N atoms for firmly trapping metal atom [20,23]. The reported coordination structure of g-C3N4 confining isolated metal atom principally focused on M-N4 (M is metal) considering its lower formation energy [23,30]. According to the proposed Fe-N2O2 structure, the coordination model was proposed by combining two pyridine nitrogen atoms on the adjacent tri-s-triazine ring with the Fe atom by the FeO2 bond. The Fe-N2O2 structure exhibited two formation energies of − 5.631 eV and − 5.636 eV, which were both obviously lower than that of Fe-N4 (− 2.77 eV) [30]. This supported the feasibility of dispersing single atom Fe in g-C3N4 matrix and stability of Fe-N2O2 coordination structure.

The XPS spectra of pristine g-C3N4 and 5-SAFe-CN are displayed in Fig. 3a and b. The major peak at 288.3 eV in C 1s XPS spectrum was attributed to the CN–C coordination structure in the triazine aromatic ring. Other characteristics peaks at the binding energies of 284.8, 286.3 and 293.5 eV were assigned to C-C, C-NH2 and pi-pi shake up, respectively. It is noted that the fraction of CN–C elevates as single atom Fe dispersed in g-C3N4 while that of C-NH2 decreases (Fig. 3c and d). This could be explained by that single atom Fe slightly destructed triazine aromatic ring network or changed polymerization of melamine monomer in pyrolysis. Similar phenomenon could be observed in N 1s spectrum. Proportion of CN–C and N-C3 in 5-SAFe-CN is smaller than that in pristine g-C3N4, which may be due to the coordination between N in CN-C with single atom Fe.

OPP decomposition via PMS activation by x-SAFe-CN, g-C3N4 and the benchmark catalysts (carbon nano-tube and Co3O4) was shown in Fig. 4a. Some studies indicated unactivated PMS could directly degrade organic pollutants [31], while the elimination effect using PMS alone was negligible in this work (Fig. S4). Pristine g-C3N4 exhibited a fast adsorption equilibrium within 2 min with only 25% of OPP removal (Fig. 4a), which was similar to the adsorption capacity of 5-SAFe-CN (Fig. S4). The catalytic performance was obviously enhanced after the anchoring of Fe single atom in g-C3N4. Complete removal of OPP was achieved within 30 and 60 min by 5-SAFe-CN and 10-SAFe-CN, respectively. However, 20-SAFe-CN exhibited a poor catalytic performance with only 38% of OPP removal within 90 min, which could be ascribed to the low Fe amount (0.93 wt‰) in 20-SAFe-CN as compared with those (3.77 and 7.33 wt‰) in 10-SAFe-CN and 5-SAFe-CN (Table S4). Besides, LRA showed that the k obs of x-SAFe-CN keep linear dependence with the Fe content (R
2 = 0.943, Fig. S5). However, the synthesized Fe-NP-CN exhibited a poor OPP removal efficiency (Fig. 4a) though it has a higher Fe contents (39.3‰, Table S4), indicating superiority of single atom catalysts. All these results indicated the introduction of single atom endowed the inactive g-C3N4 with excellent catalytic activity. In addition, the catalytic performances of CNT and Co3O4 (benchmark catalysts for non-radicals and radicals reactions) showed significantly lower catalytic performances than that of SAFe-CN, which indicated the exceptional excellent catalytic activity of SAFe-CN. Besides, 5-SAFe-CN exhibited the stable adsorption and catalytic performances in a wide pH range (pH 3.0–11.0, Fig. 4b). Interestingly, the optimal OPP removal was achieved at pH 11.0 because of simultaneous base activation of PMS [32,33].

The ROS involved in catalytic oxidation process were unveiled by scavenger experiments ( Fig. 5a). Ethanol (EtOH) was frequently applied to quench SO4 •− and •OH with a high reactivity (k SO4 •− ,EtOH = 1.6 × 107 M−1s−1 and k •OH, EtOH = 1.9 × 109 M−1 s−1) [34]. Different from traditional radicals dominated reactions in Fe based catalysts/PMS systems, EtOH show negligible inhibition effect on OPP removal in 5-SAFe-CN/PMS system. TBA, the typical •OH quencher (k •OH, TBA = 7.6 × 108 M−1 s−1), also exhibited negligible inhibitory effect. These results implied the single atom Fe site dispersed on g-C3N4 exhibited distinct underlying PMS activation mechanism (non-radicals pathway) as compared with micron/nano Fe catalysts, suggesting unique role of electronic structure of Fe single atom.

Organic pollutants degradation in the absence of SO4 •− and •OH has often initiated speculation that 1O2 was the responsible reactive species because 1O2 is inert to typical scavengers of SO4 •− and •OH [8,35]. FFA was recently selected as scavenger of 1O2 due to its high reactivity with 1O2 (
k
O
2
1
1
, FFA
= 1.2 × 108 M−1 s−1) [35]. As 20 mM FFA was added, the degradation of OPP was significantly inhibited within 120 min, suggesting potential contribution of 1O2 (Fig. 5a). Effect of serial FFA concentration on OPP removal was further conducted (Fig. S7) and the inhibitory effect enhanced with increased FFA concentration. Meanwhile, the EPR spectra (Fig. S8) displayed the symbolic three-line spectrum of TEMPO after adding catalyst in PMS solution. The typical single signal declined with the presence of OPP, further implying the possible involution of 1O2 in OPP degradation. Li et al. reported that single atom catalysts with CoN4 sites catalyzed PMS to generate 1O2 for organic pollutants elimination, which was supported by quenching test and EPR spectra [36]. However, some works indicated the quenching agents including NaN3 and L-histidine could react directly with the PMS, resulting in inhibition of pollutant removal [7]. Lu et al. indicated the role of 1O2 may be overestimated due to the false positive results of EPR spectra [37]. Therefore, the contribution of 1O2 needed further investigation considering the debatable role of 1O2 and deficiency of quench agents [1,7].

Generally, 1O2 generation could be produced through ketone functionality in organics catalyzing PMS in alkaline environment or PMS self−decay (HSO5 − + SO5 2− → HSO4 − + SO4 2−+ 1O2) [38]. However, the acid-base equilibrium of PMS releases a large amount of H+, promoting acid aqueous environment (pH 3.0), and PMS self−decay is relatively inefficient (k = 4.7 − 5.9 × 10−2 M−1 s−1) [39]. Some recent studies suggested an alternative mechanism that •O2 − acts as the intermediate to produce 1O2 by proton-promoted disproportionation (•O2 − + •HO2 → 1O2 + HO2 −) [40]. BQ was applied as scavenger of •O2 − to inhibit 1O2 generation (Fig. 5a). However, the OPP removal was not influenced by the addition of 5 mM BQ, suggesting that the generation of 1O2 via •O2 − was negligible. Besides, the generation of reactive oxygen species (SO4 •−, •OH, 1O2 and •O2 −) inherently initiates with one-electron reduction of PMS, hence the solution-phase electron could be quenched by K2Cr2O7, which could inhibit the possible ROS generation [41]. However, the addition of 2 and 10 mM K2Cr2O7 in 5-SAFe-CN/PMS system had no effect on OPP removal (Fig. 5a and Fig. S9), indicating that ROS involvement was negligible. So the role of FFA in PMS based AOPs seemed controversial and insufficiently clear.

Could be FFA oxidized by other non-radicals pathway such as mediated electron transfer? Ren el al. proposed “compulsory” electron-transfer at an inert electrode could create analogies of mediated electron transfer process in AOPs [10]. The cyclic voltammetry (CV) plots of FFA are shown in Fig. 5b. Segment 1 of CV plots exhibited two anodic peaks (peak 1a and peak 2a) at ~ 0.2 and ~ 0.45 V, which corresponded with two oxidation reaction of FFA. In segment 2 and 3, the intermediates experienced a new oxidation process with a new anodic peak. This result suggested that FFA could be oxidized by mediated electron transfer mechanism, further indicating that the inhibition of FFA on OPP removal in 5-SAFe-CN/PMS system might not be derived from quenching 1O2 but competitive capture of direct transfer electron. In combination with BQ and K2Cr2O7 quenching tests, the inhibition of FFA may not be ascribed to the consumption of 1O2 produced, but to competitive oxidation on catalyst surface via mediated electron transfer. The FFA degradation in 5-SAFe-CN/PMS system is further displayed in Fig. 5c and Fig. S10. Approximately 48.4% of FFA was degraded in 5-SAFe-CN/PMS system, indicated the possible direct oxidation by mediated electron transfer.

To further confirm the contribution of 1O2, photogenic 1O2 generation system was performed (Fig. 5d and S9). Photoexcited BR system is a classical method to generate 1O2 and used to degrade different pollutants for comparing the kinetics difference with 5-SAFe-CN/PMS system [42]. It was obvious that the pseudo-first-order kinetics rate constant (0.5213 min−1) of 2,4,6-TCPdegradation in BR-1O2 system was almost 50 times higher than that of OPP (0.0118 min−1) and PE (0.0096 min−1). Besides, only 65% of OPP and 58% of PE were eliminated in 90 min while 100% of 2,4,6-TCP was thoroughly removed in 15 min. However, similar reactivity with OPP, PE and 2,4,6-TCP in 5-SAFe-CN/PMS system was observed, which can be eliminated within 30 min (Fig. S11). These results indicates the reaction mechanism of 5-SAFe-CN/PMS system is different from 1O2 based system, which exhibited low reactivity with neutral phenols [1]. It has been documented that TEMPO adduct could also be produced via deprotonation and O2 addition of TEMP+•, which were derived from direct electron transfer of TEMP (electron donor) [43]. N2 aeration in SAFe-CN/PMS system resulted in significant decrease of symbolic three-line spectrum (Fig. 5e), implying the negligible contribution of 1O2 and possible direct electron transfer mechanism.

Some studies have also reported the high-valent Fe-Oxo (HV-Fe) species dominated the PMS activation mechanism in Fe-based AOPs [44]. The mechanism was confirmed as PMS bound with Fe(III)-N moieties to generate FeV=O and FeIV=O species, which could efficiently eliminate organic pollutants. There were similar Fe-N moieties in 5-SAFe-CN and results of quenching tests as reported [44]. To identify possible HV-Fe species, oxalate was used to impede formation of HV-Fe. When the Fe sites were coordinated with carboxyl groups of oxalate, the formation of FeV=O and FeIV=O species were inhibited, further hindering pollutant removal [11]. Effect of oxalate on OPP removal is exhibited in Fig. 6a. Oxalate could terminated target pollutants removal in HV-Fe dominated catalytic system [45], but the OPP removal was slightly inhibited after adding oxalate in SAFe-CN/PMS system [11], suggesting the HV-Fe may be not involved. The inhibitory effect of oxalate could be ascribed to the increased pH after adding oxalate (Fig. 6a). What’s more, DMSO, the scavenger of HV-Fe, was also applied to detect HV-Fe (Fig. 6b). The OPP removal was not inhibited as DMSO increased from 2 to 10 mM, indicating the absence of HV-Fe. PMSO2 has also been widely used as the HV-Fe probe. Although oxidizing agents such as IKO4, HClO and PDS can directly oxidize PMSO to PMSO2, the generation rate of PMSO2 is faster in HV-Fe system [46]. As compared with PMS solo system, PMSO2 generation was not accelerated in the 5-SAFe-CN/PMS system which indicated that the HV-Fe was not generated (Fig. S13). In fact, a slight decrease of PMSO2 generation was observed in 5-SAFe-CN/PMS system; this might be partially due to the adsorption of a small fraction of PMS molecules onto the 5-SAFe-CN, which resulted in the reduce of PMSO2.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Evidences for mediated electron transfer mechanism
ce:section.ce:para: The mediated electron transfer reaction occurs when PMS and organic pollutants simultaneously participate in the reaction process, while the ROS (SO4 •−, •OH, 1O2 and •O2 −) generation could be triggered as solo PMS was adsorbed by the catalyst with the absence of organic pollutants [10,16]. The residual PMS was measured after activating PMS by 5-SAFe-CN and benchmark catalyst (Co3O4, radicals-based catalyst) with/without the presence of OPP ( Fig. 7a). For Co3O4, PMS abidingly decomposed over time because PMS was activated by Co3O4 to generate radicals (SO4 •− and •OH,) which was instantaneous and short-lived (t1/2 = 10−6–10−9 s) [47]. In contrast, residual PMS concentration remained unchanged after 20 min in 5-SAFe-CN/PMS system. This further suggested that PMS was adsorbed on the surface of 5-SAFe-CN rather than being decomposed as occurred in the Co3O4/PMS system. However, the presence of OPP led to PMS consumption in the 5-SAFe-CN/PMS system, and the continuous electron transfer decomposed the PMS into SO4 2− [7]. In particular, low concentration of organic pollutants would lead to additional waste of PMS due to the fact that PMS will spontaneously decompose and generate free radicals after contacting with traditional iron-based catalysts, requiring rapid quenching without reaction with organic pollutants [48]. On the contrary, electron transfer-based catalytic processes can avoid this defect and improve the utilization efficiency of PMS. The decomposition of PMS by 0.6 g/L Co3O4 (whose OPP degradation rate was close to that of 5-SAFe-CN) was greater than that of 5-SAFe-CN (Fig. S14), verifying the superiority of mediated electron transfer mechanism.

Meanwhile, the mediated electron transfer mechanism in 5-SAFe-CN/PMS system was further elucidated by electrochemical methods. The potentials of 5-SAFe-CN after mixing PMS and OPP were recorded by chronopotentiometry (CP). The solo 5-SAFe-CN exhibited almost invariable potential at ~ 0.2 V. When OPP was mixed in solution, the potentials still remain constant at ~ 0.2 V. However, the potential after adding PMS rose rapidly from ~ 0.2 V to ~ 0.95 V and stabilized at ~ 1.0 V (Fig. 7b). This phenomenon can be described as the formation of compounds with high redox potential by the adsorption of PMS onto 5-SAFe-CN, and the adsorption equilibrium is gradually reached and the potential tends to be stable [10]. However, the presence of OPP led to a decrease in potential to nearly 0.4 V, which was due to the PMS decomposition after accepting the electron from OPP [10,16]. The i-t curves recorded the current change at open-circuit voltage (Fig. 7c). No significant change of current was observed after the addition of PMS, but the current changed rapidly after the addition of OPP, indicating that PMS and organic pollutants acted on the surface of the catalyst to trigger the electron transfer reaction, which was consistent with the PMS decomposition experiment.

DMPOX (5,5dimethyl-2-pyrrolidone-N-oxyl) is an indicator of mediated electron transfer mechanism as it is a direct oxidation product of DMPO [49]. In 5-SAFe-CN/PMS system, clear signals of DMPOX were detected (Fig. 7d), which confirmed the mediated electron transfer mechanism and the absence of •OH and SO4 •−.

ce:section.ce:section-title: The role of single atom Fe and catalytic mechanism
ce:section.ce:para: Pristine g-C3N4 showed negligible catalytic activity for PMS (Fig. 4a), but strong activation performance on PMS was endowed as it was coordinated with single atom Fe. Therefore, two fundamental questions remain ambiguous: (i) how does the anchored single atom Fe change the physicochemical characteristics of the g-C3N4? (ii) what is the role of single atom Fe in mediated electron transfer mechanism? To solve above questions, DFT calculations using VASP were employed to investigate the properties of g-C3N4 and SAFe-CN including density of states, Laplacian distribution of electron density and difference charge density of PMS adsorption. The total density of states (TDOS) is shown in Fig. S15 and the calculated Fermi level (Ef) is exhibited in Table 1. As compared with the pristine g-C3N4, the Fermi level of SAFe-CN shifted upward from − 4.25 eV to − 2.90 eV, demonstrating that SAFe-CN was a better electron donor. The band gap of SAFe-CN still located in 1.0–3.0 eV (the band gap of semiconductors) but diminished to 1.46 eV (vs 1.94 eV of g-C3N4), which was in favor of separation and transfer of electrons. Meanwhile, the electron distribution of g-C3N4 was disturbed by the isolated Fe atom (Fig. S16). These results indicated that the isolated single Fe atom in g-C3N4 could obviously enhance the chemical activity by promoting electron transfer and changing electron distribution.

To further give insight into the role of single atom Fe, the Laplacian of the electron density of pristine g-C3N4 and SAFe-CN are evaluated and given in Fig. 8a and b. Strong electron aggregation was observed between C and N atom in both pristine g-C3N4 and SAFe-CN, which was attributed to the localized electrons of polar covalent bond. Apparently, stronger electron aggregation occurred around N atom than C atom, partially due to the more electronegativity of N. In g-C3N4, delocalized π electrons in triazine ring constituted the electron density region where electron tended to diverge, and evenly distributed over the carbon nitride frameworks (Fig. 8a). However, this caused low efficiency donating electron to PMS molecule, coupled with poor electron transfer ability of g-C3N4, resulting in its negligible catalytic performance. With the introduction of single Fe atom, the divergent electron density region concentrated on Fe and O atom, which could easily donate electron after bond with PMS molecule. It is noted that the divergent electrons density in triazine ring declined because delocalized π electron partially transferred to FeO2 bonding, further promoting triazine ring to accept electron from other substance such as organic pollutants [50]. Hence, an electron transfer pathway was established according to the mentioned results.

The fully relaxed PMS adsorption configurations of g-C3N4 and SAFe-CN were also optimized and calculated with difference charge density to further clarify the mediated electron transfer mechanism. Integrated with the top view and front view of optimized configuration (Fig. S17), the adsorption of PMS molecule onto g-C3N4 was attributed to Vander Waals force between triazine ring in g-C3N4 and SO bond in PMS [51]. Interestingly, the PMS molecule gradually keep far away from g-C3N4 layer and the adsorbed sites of PMS on SAFe-CN changed to FeO2 bonding after anchoring of single atom Fe (Fig. S18). Notably, the distal OO bond of PMS dominates the activation activity of PMS and acts as the responsible action site with the catalysts, which is conducive to electron transfer and bond cleavage. The difference charge density of PMS on g-C3N4 and SAFe-CN are exhibited in Fig. 8c and d. An obvious electron depletion on g-C3N4 was observed on contact surface (Side A) after PMS adsorption. Integrated with the front views and side views (Fig. S19), electron accumulation occurred on the other side (Side B) of g-C3N4 and S-adjacent O atoms. This electron distribution configuration would impede catalyst donate electron to PMS, resulting in poor catalytic performance of g-C3N4. Different from g-C3N4, SAFe-CN exhibited partial electron depletion on OO bond and significant electron accumulation on FeO2 bonding [51], which ensured that OO bond did not break immediately and facilitated subsequent electron transfer from Fe-O2 to OO bond after accepting electron from organic pollutants. These results profoundly explained the poor catalytic performance of g-C3N4, intrinsic mechanism of mediated electron transfer on SAFe-CN and the role of single atom Fe as the working sites for PMS.

Results of LRA verified the prediction by theoretical calculation. The adsorption capacity of SAFe-CN for PMS increased with the Fe content in SAFe-CN (Fig. 8e). A good linear correlation was established between equilibrium adsorption capacity (qe, mM/g) and Fe content (wt‰) with R
2 = 0.9744 (Fig. 8f), while the R
2 value (0.8766) for linear correlation between specific area (SA) and qe was relatively lower (Fig. 8g). This also suggested that the atomically dispersed Fe can act as the adsorption sites for PMS and potential electron temporary residences for electron transfer. As compared with Li’s work, the central metal atoms with unsaturated coordination would not directly catalyze PMS to generate ROS, but served as electron temporary residences to transfer electron from OPP to PMS [36]. The adsorption sites for OPP were considered as triazine framework because the adsorption capacity and kinetics of g-C3N4 for OPP were similar to those of 5-SAFe-CN (Fig. 4a). The typical OPP degradation progress in 5-SAFe-CN/PMS system was proposed as that the OPP molecules was first adsorbed on the triazine framework of 5-SAFe-CN and then donated electron. The electron was mediated from triazine ring to the FeO2 bonding and then to the OO bond of PMS, leading to cleavage of OO bond and generation of sulfate and hydroxide.

High concentration of anions have obvious inhibition effect on the removal of target pollutants in radicals dominated catalytic process [52,53]. Non-radical pathways are of great interest because of the salt tolerance, which is meaningful for practical application. In 5-SAFe-CN/PMS system, the inhibitory effect was not observed after adding 20 mM of Cl−, HCO3 −, NO3 − and H2PO4 − ( Fig. 9a), indicating the superiority of mediated electron transfer mechanism. The presence of high concentration of Cl− can slightly enhance the degradation of OPP, which is due to the formation of HClO (reaction between Cl− and PMS) oxidizing OPP [8]. The great potential of 5-SAFe-CN encouraged further exploration of its scope at the device level. A water treatment filter was fabricated by coating 5-SAFe-CN on carbon felt (cross-sectional area 1 cm2 and length 5 cm) and sealing the coated carbon felt into epoxy resin for passing wastewater (Fig. S21 and Fig. 9b) [54]. Complete elimination of OPP was achieved by 5-SAFe-CN coated filter with 20 mL/h flow and 0.4 g/L PMS (Fig. 9c). The carbon felt just exhibited 45% of OPP removal and the 5-SAFe-CN coated filter achieved saturated adsorption in 100 min (Fig. 9c). Besides, visualized removal process by 5-SAFe-CN coated filter was displayed in Supplementary Video by using 10 mg/L Rhodamine B as target pollutants and the filter achieved 100% dye elimination. After 100 h operation, the filter still remained 100% of OPP removal (Fig. 9d), demonstrating the outstanding potential of 5-SAFe-CN in practical application.

In this work, the atomically dispersed Fe catalyst (SAFe-CN) with unique N, O unsaturated coordination was successfully synthesized to activate PMS for contaminant degradation. Due to the limitation of ROS scavengers and the controversy of catalytic pathway, a series of experiments were designed to uncover the catalytic mechanism in SAFe-CN /PMS system. Different from the common Fe-based catalysts, SAFe-CN/PMS system unexpectedly showed the mediated electron transfer mechanism. This suggested the novel physico-chemical properties of single atom Fe catalyst. Importantly, mediated electron transfer mechanism could improve the utilization efficiency of PMS because PMS adsorbed on SAFe-CN would remain stable rather than spontaneous decomposition as compared with other radicals and non-radicals pathways. Anchoring of isolated Fe atom on g-C3N4 could obviously improve electron transfer of catalyst via reducing band gap. Theoretical calculation coupled with LRA further illuminated that the atomically dispersed Fe moieties with N, O unsaturated coordination could serve as the active sites for PMS adsorption and activation. Mediated electron transfer dominated SAFe-CN/PMS system exhibited more efficient utilization of PMS and excellent salt tolerance. The SAFe-CN coated water treatment filter achieved complete pollutants removal with continuous operation for 100 h, providing a promising technology for sustainable remediation of organic pollution in aqueous environment.

Pijun Duan: Conceptualization, Methodology, Formal analysis, Investigation, Writing – original draft, Visualization. Jingwen Pan: Investigation. Weiyan Du: Software, Visualization. Qinyan Yue: Validation, Funding acquisition. Baoyu Gao: Validation, Writing – review & editing, Funding acquisition, Supervision. Xing Xu: Writing – review & editing, Funding acquisition.
